pullRequest.body:
We define the group homomorphism Aut(L)->(Z/dZ)^* coming from the action on the n'th roots of unity in L. Here d is the number of n'th roots of unity in L (which might not be n in this generality).

We also make API for the standard special case when there are n n'th roots of unity in L, calling it `ModularCyclotomicCharacter`.

Joint work with Hanneke Wiersema, coming from the Leiden conference on machine checked mathematics.

---

(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

- [x] depends on: #11075

nodes.body: Eric Rodriguez has pointed out the related declaration https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/RootsOfUnity/Basic.html#IsPrimitiveRoot.autToPow  which probably means that I'd like another think about this PR (autToPow is weaker than what we have here but perhaps I can use it to make some proofs shorter?)

the whole file works just as well with `CommRing` + `IsDomain`. Should this not be going to some units group morally? Not that I know the nice way to implement this. I guess the only plug in that can be done with `autToPow` is for the case where the primitive root exists (I see why on Zulip you said this is fundamentally different, Kevin)
Ah yes, `MonoidHom.toHomUnits` also works here, of course

Thanks Eric: I changed field to integral domain. I don't like autToPow because it depends on the choice of a primitive root. My instinct is to replace autToPow by my definition and weaken the hypotheses to just the statement that a primitive root exists (in a future PR).

Yes, I think that's a good idea. I think there's also some possibility that it's nice to have this instead be an equiv to `ZMod d`^x, with proving that d is equal to the size of the group of roots of unity instead. I think it'd give nicer definitional equalities for the autToPow use-case (gal group of cycl extension) and if it's unwanted then we can just use `rfl`
This depends on your other PR, right? Can you mark it in the description? Thanks!

> This depends on your other PR, right? Can you mark it in the description? Thanks!

OK! I had just left it tagged awaiting-author and was waiting for the other PR to be merged, but if you think it's OK to just make it a dependent PR I can tag it awaiting-review now (I am never quite sure of the etiquette here).

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#11075~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

In your overall set-up, your field $L$ is fixed and you consider the group of its (ring) automorphisms as domain for $\chi_0$. This prevents you from considering the cyclotomic character relative to a fixed "base" field in the following sense: if $F/K$ is an extension of number fields (say...) both embedded in $L=F(\zeta_{p^{\infty}})$ then you only get an "absolute" cyclotomic character rather than one, $\chi_K$, relative to $K$ and one, $\chi_F$ relative to $F$ whose image will possibly be a proper subgroup of the image of $\chi_K$. Now, it seems to me that it is useful to keep track of this information and with your construction one would constantly need to change $\chi_0$ to a suitable power to get a new character whose image is the one you are interested in.

I wonder if the construction should not rather be parametrised over an algebra $L/K$ and the domain should be the $K$-algebra isomorphisms of $L$. This would make it more compatible with the definition of the absolute Galois group we have now in Mathlib.

@faenuccio There's a canonical forgetful group homomorphism from Gal(L/K) to the group of field automorphisms of L, and all I have to do to get your vision of the modular cyclotomic character is to just compose with this map. Are you suggesting I made this composition into a new definition?

> @faenuccio There's a canonical forgetful group homomorphism from Gal(L/K) to the group of field automorphisms of L, and all I have to do to get your vision of the modular cyclotomic character is to just compose with this map. Are you suggesting I made this composition into a new definition?

Yes, I am suggesting that you create also a "relative" cyclotomic character, either by doing as you suggest or by defining it as a group hom from $\mathrm{Aut}_K(L)\to (\mathbb{Z}/d)^\times$, and prove some results like $\chi_K^a=\chi_L$ where $a$ is the index of $\mu_K$ inside $\mu_L$. I think that this gadget is the one that really shows off more often e.g. in interpolating special values of $L$-functions beyond Dirichlet ones. What troubles me with this "absolute" definition is that if I am working over $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_p)$ I would like the image of the cyclotomic character to be pro- $p$ , for instance. 

Lean-wise, if you will want to twist a Galois rep of $G_K$ by a power of it, you will constantly need to compose the absolute one with the group hom you speak about, and this can be painful especially when letting $K$ vary.

> > @faenuccio There's a canonical forgetful group homomorphism from Gal(L/K) to the group of field automorphisms of L, and all I have to do to get your vision of the modular cyclotomic character is to just compose with this map. Are you suggesting I made this composition into a new definition?
> 
> Yes, I am suggesting that you create also a "relative" cyclotomic character, either by doing as you suggest or by defining it as a group hom from AutK(L)â†’(Z/d)Ã—, and prove some results like Ï‡Ka=Ï‡L where a is the index of Î¼K inside Î¼L. I think that this gadget is the one that really shows off more often e.g. in interpolating special values of L-functions beyond Dirichlet ones. What troubles me with this "absolute" definition is that if I am working over Q(Î¶p) I would like the image of the cyclotomic character to be pro- p , for instance.
> 
> Lean-wise, if you will want to twist a Galois rep of GK by a power of it, you will constantly need to compose the absolute one with the group hom you speak about, and this can be painful especially when letting K vary.

Do you think we need to replace this one with your version, or we want both?

> > > @faenuccio There's a canonical forgetful group homomorphism from Gal(L/K) to the group of field automorphisms of L, and all I have to do to get your vision of the modular cyclotomic character is to just compose with this map. Are you suggesting I made this composition into a new definition?
> > 
> > 
> > Yes, I am suggesting that you create also a "relative" cyclotomic character, either by doing as you suggest or by defining it as a group hom from AutK(L)â†’(Z/d)Ã—, and prove some results like Ï‡Ka=Ï‡L where a is the index of Î¼K inside Î¼L. I think that this gadget is the one that really shows off more often e.g. in interpolating special values of L-functions beyond Dirichlet ones. What troubles me with this "absolute" definition is that if I am working over Q(Î¶p) I would like the image of the cyclotomic character to be pro- p , for instance.
> > Lean-wise, if you will want to twist a Galois rep of GK by a power of it, you will constantly need to compose the absolute one with the group hom you speak about, and this can be painful especially when letting K vary.
> 
> Do you think we need to replace this one with your version, or we want both?

I think I would keep both. On a one hand, this one can be useful to construct the other one and on the other hand one might want to simply use the map leaving from $\mathrm{Aut}(L)$ as a field. Probably, though, I would call my version the cyclotomic "character" and this one something else (cyclotomic hom?).

I think we merge this and generalize it later, thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

I am wondering whether it makes sense to connect this with [MulChar](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/NumberTheory/LegendreSymbol/MulCharacter.html#MulChar). Maybe it's very relevant, since the main point of `MulChar` is to have a ring as domain. @MichaelStollBayreuth what do you think?

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ZMod.val_int_cast, â† Group.pow_eq_zpow_mod _ pow_card_eq_one] ```

```suggestion
lemma ringEquivCongr_val {a b : â„•} (h : a = b) (x : ZMod a) :
```
If you think keeping them explicit no problem.

Right now, I don't quite see how to connect this to `MulChar` in a meaningful way: the character here is on the automorphism group, which is just a group and not a ring. Of course, technically, one can define a `MulChar` on a commutative monoid with values in `ZMod d` (with the extra condition on non-units vacuous when it is in fact a group), but in general the automorphism group in question may not even be commutative.

```suggestion
  simpa using rootsOfUnity.integer_power_of_ringEquiv n g
```

```suggestion
theorem Group.pow_eq_zpow_mod {G : Type _} [Group G] {x : G} (m : â„¤) {n : â„•} (h : x ^ n = 1) :
    x ^ m = x ^ (m % (n : â„¤)) :=
  calc
    x ^ m = x ^ (m % n + n * (m / n)) := by rw [Int.emod_add_ediv]
    _ = x ^ (m % (n : â„¤)) := by simp [zpow_add, zpow_mul, h]
```
This can go just after [pow_eq_pow_mod](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/GroupPower/Basic.html#pow_eq_pow_mod) or maybe after [zpow_eq_zpow_iff_modEq](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/GroupTheory/OrderOfElement.html#zpow_eq_zpow_iff_modEq) (you can use this last one to prove it, or maybe even use directly the lemma in the library).
Nice! I've split this off as #11009 . Sorry, I opened this PR but forgot to move a couple of proofs to where they were supposed to be beforehand!
#11009 is now merged.

This can go in the file where cyclic groups are defined. I think that the good statement is that if `g` is a generator of a cyclic group of order `d`, then for all `x` in the group there is a unique n in `Zmod d` (or `Fin d`) such that `x = g ^ n`.
I've put both lemmas in #11016
`Ï‡ n g` is the unique element with this property, right (as a term of type `ZMod`). Can you add this characterization? I think it can golf certain proofs below.
Now added as `ModularCyclotomicCharacter.unique` (and indeed I could golf `id` and `comp`).

```suggestion
multiplicative homomorphism from the automorphisms of a field `L` to `(â„¤/dâ„¤)Ë£`,
```
Can you add a proof that "It is uniquely characterized by the property that..."? Similarly below.

```suggestion
theorem Group.pow_eq_zpow_mod {G : Type*} [Group G] {x : G} (m : â„¤) {n : â„•} (h : x ^ n = 1) :
```
Fixed in #11009

```suggestion
lemma ext {G : Type*} [Group G] [Fintype G] [IsCyclic G]
```
Fixed in #11016
`n` could be `Nat` and implicit here (the cardinality in `hn` cannot be zero).
Unfortunately `rootsOfUnity n` needs `n : â„•+` so I don't see how to make this work.
Ah, OK. I missed that.

```suggestion
are cyclic. The advantage of sticking to integral domains is that finite subgroups
```

```suggestion
  if `n âˆ£ m`.
```
